en: The hope of causing you a regret will soothe my agony, and that thought shall be the sole revenge of a slighted heart....”
zh: 让你感到遗憾，这个希望会减轻我的苦痛，这个想法也会是对你漠不关心我的完全报复……”

en: Only those who have passed through all the exceeding tribulations of youth, who have seized on all the chimeras with two white pinions, the nightmare fancies at the disposal of a fervid imagination, can realize the horrors that seized upon Gaston de Nueil when he had reason to suppose that his ultimatum was in Mme. de Beauseant’s hands.
zh: 加斯东·德纽埃尔将这封信送出时，他感到惶恐万分，他明白，自己的命运就握在德鲍赛昂夫人手中了。想要理解这一点，必须要经历过年轻时期的一切超级难关，必须要曾经捕获过长有白色双翼的喀迈拉，经受过噩梦般激烈的想象。

en: He saw the Vicomtesse, wholly untouched, laughing at his letter and his love, as those can laugh who have ceased to believe in love.
zh: 他仿佛看到子爵夫人完全无动于衷，正在在嘲笑他的信和他的爱，正如那些不再相信爱情的人一样。

en: He could have wished to have his letter back again.
zh: 他真希望把自己的信要回来。

en: It was an absurd letter.
zh: 这是一封荒唐的信。

en: There were a thousand and one things, now that he came to think of it, that he might have said, things infinitely better and more moving than those stilted phrases of his, those accursed, sophisticated, pretentious, fine-spun phrases, though, luckily, the punctuation had been pretty bad and the lines shockingly crooked.
zh: 有一千零一种想法在头脑中浮现，他觉察到，这些想法要比他写的那些矫揉造作的句子，那些该死的、诡辩的、自命不凡而又精挑细选的句子，不知要优秀和感人多少倍。幸好，他的标点错得相当厉害，字迹也写得歪三扭四。

en: He tried not to think, not to feel; but he felt and thought, and was wretched.
zh: 他尽可能不去想，不去感知；可是他感觉到了，也想到了，他痛苦得很。

en: If he had been thirty years old, he might have got drunk, but the innocence of three-and-twenty knew nothing of the resources of opium nor of the expedients of advanced civilization.
zh: 要是他30岁的话，他一定会一醉不醒，可是23岁的清纯少年既不知道鸦片的效果也不知道先进文明的各种办法。

en: Nor had he at hand one of those good friends of the Parisian pattern who understand so well how to say Poete, non dolet! by producing a bottle of champagne, or alleviate the agony of suspense by carrying you off somewhere to make a night of it.
zh: 他身边也没有巴黎人那样的好朋友，他们会手捧香槟，对你说说“诗人，请勿悲伤！”，或者把你拉出去某个地方狂欢一晚，以减轻你愁疑的痛苦。

en: Capital fellows are they, always in low water when you are in funds, always off to some watering-place when you go to look them up, always with some bad bargain in horse-flesh to sell you; it is true, that when you want to borrow of them, they have always just lost their last louis at play; but in all other respects they are the best fellows on earth, always ready to embark with you on one of the steep down-grades where you lose your time, your soul, and your life!
zh: 他们是些最好的朋友，总是在你缺钱时手头拮据，你去找他们，他们总是去了温泉疗养，并且总会有一匹劣马要卖给你；你要管他们借钱，他们总会在博彩中输光最后一个铜板；不过从其他任何方面来讲，他们是世上最好的朋友，随时准备着沿着陡峭的斜坡启程出发，在此期间，你会耗尽时间，精神和生命！

en: At length M. de Nueil received a missive through the instrumentality of Jacques, a letter that bore the arms of Burgundy on the scented seal, a letter written on vellum notepaper.
zh: 最终，德纽埃尔先生从雅克手中收到一封信件，这封信件写在一张牛皮纸上，上面盖着勃艮第家族的散发有香气的封印。

en: He rushed away at once to lock himself in, and read and re-read her letter:—
zh: 他立即跑进房间，锁上房门，将她的信念了又念：

en: “You are punishing me very severely, monsieur, both for the friendliness of my effort to spare you a rebuff, and for the attraction which intellect always has for me.
zh: “先生，我出于好意而不致使你受到严词的拒绝，也是由于一位聪明人士总是会给予我吸引力的原因，可你却如此严厉地惩罚了我。

en: I put confidence in the generosity of youth, and you have disappointed me.
zh: 我相信了年轻人的慷慨大度，而你却令我感到失望。

en: And yet, if I did not speak unreservedly (which would have been perfectly ridiculous), at any rate I spoke frankly of my position, so that you might imagine that I was not to be touched by a young soul.
zh: 可是，如果你认为我已经对你开诚布公谈话的话（那绝对是极其荒唐可笑的），我至少向你坦言了我的处境，目的是使自己能够远离一位年轻的灵魂。

en: My distress is the keener for my interest in you.
zh: 我的悲痛要大于你对我的兴趣。

en: I am naturally tender-hearted and kindly, but circumstances force me to act unkindly.
zh: 我生性温柔、善良，可是环境逼迫我不近人情。

en: Another woman would have flung your letter, unread, into the fire; I read it, and I am answering it.
zh: 换作别的女人，你的信会连读也不读就付之一炬；我读了，而且我也在给你回信。

en: My answer will make it clear to you that while I am not untouched by the expression of this feeling which I have inspired, albeit unconsciously, I am still far from sharing it, and the step which I am about to take will show you still more plainly that I mean what I say.
zh: 我的回答向你证明，即便我对你因为我所产生的感情不是不受感动，虽然是不知不觉，我也绝不会和你一起分享这份感情，我接下来要采取的行动依然会更加明白，我言出必行。

en: I wish besides, to use, for your welfare, that authority, as it were, which you give me over your life; and I desire to exercise it this once to draw aside the veil from your eyes.
zh: 为了你好，我还是希望使用一次正如你所赐予我的对你生命的权力，揭开蒙在你双眼的那层面纱。

en: “I am nearly thirty years old, monsieur; you are barely two-and-twenty.
zh: “先生，我都快30了；而你才不过23岁。

en: You yourself cannot know what your thoughts will be at my age.
zh: 你自己无论如何不会明白我这个年龄的想法。

en: The vows that you make so lightly to-day may seem a very heavy burden to you then.
zh: 你今天轻率的誓言到时候会成为你沉重的负担。

en: I am quite willing to believe that at this moment you would give me your whole life without a regret, you would even be ready to die for a little brief happiness; but at the age of thirty experience will take from you the very power of making daily sacrifices for my sake, and I myself should feel deeply humiliated if I accepted them.
zh: 你能毫无怨无悔地为我牺牲全部生命，为了我的些许幸福而随时去死，对此我很愿意相信这是真的；可是当你到了30岁，经验会使你没有力量为我天天做出牺牲，如果我接受了这些牺牲的话，我则会感到羞愧无比。

en: A day would come when everything, even Nature, would bid you leave me, and I have already told you that death is preferable to desertion.
zh: 终究会有一天，一切甚至是自然，会强制你离开我，我已经告诉过你，我宁愿选择去死，也不愿意被遗弃。

en: Misfortune has taught me to calculate; as you see, I am arguing perfectly dispassionately.
zh: 不幸让我学会了如何打算；你看，我和你争辩时，极其冷静。

en: You force me to tell you that I have no love for you; I ought not to love, I cannot, and I will not.
zh: 是你逼迫我非要告诉你，我不爱你；我不该爱你，不能爱你，将来也不会爱你。

en: It is too late to yield, as women yield, to a blind unreasoning impulse of the heart, too late to be the mistress whom you seek.
zh: 女人不加思量地屈服于自己的内心冲动，会后悔莫及，若成为了你追求的情妇也将会令人悔迟。

en: My consolations spring from God, not from earth.
zh: 我的安慰源自于上帝，而非尘世。

en: Ah, and besides, with the melancholy insight of disappointed love, I read hearts too clearly to accept your proffered friendship.
zh: 啊，除此之外，我带着对失望爱情的忧伤见解，对人心已看得很透，因此不能接受你所提出的友谊。

en: It is only instinct.
zh: 这只是本能而已。

en: I forgive the boyish ruse, for which you are not responsible as yet.
zh: 我原谅你这孩子气的诡计，因为你连责任都还不该负。

en: In the name of this passing fancy of yours, for the sake of your career and my own peace of mind, I bid you stay in your own country; you must not spoil a fair and honorable life for an illusion which, by its very nature, cannot last.
zh: 以你这短暂爱情的名义，为了你的前途和我心境的平和，我命令你留在自己的国度；不许你为了一个必定不会持久的幻想而失去一种美好而光荣的生活。

en: At a later day, when you have accomplished your real destiny, in the fully developed manhood that awaits you, you will appreciate this answer of mine, though to-day it may be that you blame its hardness.
zh: 尽管现在你可能会骂我这封信的冷酷无情，可是总有一天，当你实现了自己的真正使命，完全具备了男子气概之后，你就会欣赏我的这些话了。

en: You will turn with pleasure to an old woman whose friendship will certainly be sweet and precious to you then; a friendship untried by the extremes of passion and the disenchanting processes of life; a friendship which noble thoughts and thoughts of religion will keep pure and sacred.
zh: 到那时，你会发现有一个老妇人仍然是你的朋友，她的友谊甜蜜而珍贵；她饱含爱情的风霜，生活淡定，却并未屈服于生活；她高尚的思想和宗教观念使她纯洁而神圣。

en: Farewell; do my bidding with the thought that your success will bring a gleam of pleasure into my solitude, and only think of me as we think of absent friends.”
zh: 再见了；照我说的做，你的成功会使我估计的生活倍感欣慰，不要想念我，要么就如同想念其他朋友一样地想念我。”

en: Gaston de Nueil read the letter, and wrote the following lines:—
zh: 加斯东·德纽埃尔读完这封信后，写了下面的话：

en: “MADAME,—If I could cease to love you, to take the chances of becoming an ordinary man which you hold out to me, you must admit that I should thoroughly deserve my fate.
zh: “夫人，如果我能够停止爱你，像你说得成为一个普通人的话，那么你一定会承认，我活该倒霉了。

en: No, I shall not do as you bid me; the oath of fidelity which I swear to you shall only be absolved by death.
zh: 不，我不会听从你的命令；我会坚持我的忠诚誓言直到死亡。

en: Ah! take my life, unless indeed you do not fear to carry a remorse all through your own—”
zh: 啊，把我的命带走吧，除非你不怕在你的生命中徒增责备——”

en: When the man returned from his errand, M. de Nueil asked him with whom he left the note?
zh: 男仆送信回来，德纽埃尔先生问他把信交给了谁。

en: “I gave it to Mme. la Vicomtesse herself, sir; she was in her carriage and just about to start.”
zh: “先生，我把它交给了子爵夫人本人；她在马车上，刚好马上要出门。”

en: “For the town?”
zh: “去城里？”

en: “I don’t think so, sir.
zh: “先生，我想不是吧。

en: Mme. la Vicomtesse had post-horses.”
zh: 子爵夫人乘的是驿马。”

en: “Ah! then she is going away,” said the Baron.
zh: “哦，那么她要出门，”男爵说道。

en: “Yes, sir,” the man answered.
zh: “是的，先生。”仆人回答道。

en: Gaston de Nueil at once prepared to follow Mme. de Beauseant.
zh: 德纽埃尔先生马上收拾一切，追随着德鲍赛昂夫人出门。

en: She led the way as far as Geneva, without a suspicion that he followed.
zh: 她驱车直到日内瓦，并没有意识到他一直跟着。

en: And he?
zh: 那么他呢？

en: Amid the many thoughts that assailed him during that journey, one all-absorbing problem filled his mind—“Why did she go away?”
zh: 一路途中他心头涌现出千万种思绪，其中充斥在脑海，挥之不去的一个问题就是——“她为什么要离开呢？”

en: Theories grew thickly on such ground for supposition, and naturally he inclined to the one that flattered his hopes—“If the Vicomtesse cares for me, a clever woman would, of course, choose Switzerland, where nobody knows either of us, in preference to France, where she would find censorious critics.”
zh: 围绕着这句话延伸出了很多种猜疑，他自然选择了一种最讨他喜欢想法——“要是子爵夫人喜欢我的话，一个聪明的女人一定会选择瑞士这个我们谁都不认识的地方，而不会选择那个她能遇见很多吹毛求疵者的法国。

en: An impassioned lover of a certain stamp would not feel attracted to a woman clever enough to choose her own ground; such women are too clever.
zh: 某些热情洋溢的男人不会喜欢一个女人聪明到自己选择场所；这样的女人太过聪明了。

en: However, there is nothing to prove that there was any truth in Gaston’s supposition.
zh: 不过，没有任何证据表明加斯东的猜想是正确无误的。

en: The Vicomtesse took a small house by the side of the lake.
zh: 子爵夫人在湖边租了一间小屋。

en: As soon as she was installed in it, Gaston came one summer evening in the twilight.
zh: 一等她安顿好，加斯东便选择了一个夏季的黄昏前来拜访。

en: Jacques, that flunkey in grain, showed no sign of surprise, and announced @M. le Baron de Nueil@ like a discreet domestic well acquainted with good society.
zh: 雅克，那个贵族的仆人，对一切都司空见惯，看到他一点也不感到惊讶，便去通报了德纽埃尔男爵先生的到来。

en: At the sound of the name, at the sight of its owner, Mme. de Beauseant let her book fall from her hands; her surprise gave him time to come close to her, and to say in tones that sounded like music in her ears:
zh: 听到名字，看到真人，德鲍赛昂夫人的书从手中掉落了下来；她的惊讶使他有时间走近她的身旁，她用在她听来美如音乐般的声音说道：

en: “What a joy it was to me to take the horses that brought you on this journey!”
zh: “我是多么高兴我旅途中所用的马正是把你带到这儿的马！”

en: To have the inmost desires of the heart so fulfilled!
zh: 这就实现了心中秘密的愿望啊！

en: Where is the woman who could resist such happiness as this?
zh: 哪一个女人能够抵挡住这样的幸福呢？

en: An Italian woman, one of those divine creatures who, psychologically, are as far removed from the Parisian as if they lived at the Antipodes, a being who would be regarded as profoundly immoral on this side of the Alps, an Italian (to resume) made the following comment on some French novels which she had been reading.
zh: 意大利女人是属于仙女般可爱的人儿，可她们在心理上却同巴黎女人截然相反，她们被阿尔卑斯山这边的人认为是很不道德的，因为意大利女人在读法国小说的时候作出了如下的评论。

en: “I cannot see,” she remarked, “why these poor lovers take such a time over coming to an arrangement which ought to be the affair of a single morning.” Why should not the novelist take a hint from this worthy lady, and refrain from exhausting the theme and the reader?
zh: “我就不明白，”她评论说，“为什么这些可怜的情郎要花这么多时间来处理只需一个早晨的时间就能处理完毕的事情呢。”为什么那个小说家不能领会这位高贵女郎的意图，缩短一下篇幅，以免使内容枯燥无味，使读者疲惫不堪呢？

en: Some few passages of coquetry it would certainly be pleasant to give in outline; the story of Mme. de Beauseant’s demurs and sweet delayings, that, like the vestal virgins of antiquity, she might fall gracefully, and by lingering over the innocent raptures of first love draw from it its utmost strength and sweetness.
zh: 这里当然有几处风流韵事必须要加以大体描述一番；德鲍赛昂夫人的犹豫和迟疑，正如古代贞洁的处女一般，纵然失身也要保全面子，为了是将初恋的纯情快乐尽情地享受，使初恋能够表现出它最强大的力量和最美好的甜蜜。

en: M. de Nueil was at an age when a man is the dupe of these caprices, of the fence which women delight to prolong; either to dictate their own terms, or to enjoy the sense of their power yet longer, knowing instinctively as they do that it must soon grow less.
zh: 德纽埃尔先生正是处于这样一种易受这些爱情游戏欺骗的年龄，对女人而言，这种藩篱她们最乐于延长；目的是要么为了守卫她们的权威，要么是想再度延长她们享受权利的时间，因为她们本能地得知自己的权力马上就会越来越削弱。

en: But, after all, these little boudoir protocols, less numerous than those of the Congress of London, are too small to be worth mention in the history of this passion.
zh: 不过，毕竟，像这些小小的闺房协议，当然比不过那些伦敦会议的内容那么繁多，因此在这些激情爱情的历史长河中太过渺小，实在是不值一提。

en: For three years Mme. de Beauseant and M. de Nueil lived in the villa on the lake of Geneva.
zh: 德鲍赛昂夫人和德纽埃尔先生在日内瓦湖边的别墅中一起居住了三年之久。

en: They lived quite alone, received no visitors, caused no talk, rose late, went out together upon the lake, knew, in short, the happiness of which we all of us dream.
zh: 他们独自安静地过活，不接见任何人，从不和人闲话，睡觉起得很晚，一起泛舟游湖，你知道，总之，如我们梦想般地过着幸福的生活。

en: It was a simple little house, with green shutters, and broad balconies shaded with awnings, a house contrived of set purpose for lovers, with its white couches, soundless carpets, and fresh hangings, everything within it reflecting their joy.
zh: 这是座简朴的小别墅，有着绿色的百叶窗，宽阔的阳台上遮着布帘，这是专为爱侣准备的屋子，里面摆放着白色沙发，踏上去没有声音的地毯，还有颜色鲜艳的帷幔，这一切都闪烁着欢乐光芒。

en: Every window looked out on some new view of the lake; in the far distance lay the mountains, fantastic visions of changing color and evanescent cloud; above them spread the sunny sky, before them stretched the broad sheet of water, never the same in its fitful changes.
zh: 从每个窗子望出去都会看到不同的新鲜景色；远处群山环绕，浮云千变万化，色彩变幻，景致奇异；头顶上阳光明媚，在他们面前是一片宽阔的水面，湖水阵阵变化，闪烁不定。

en: All their surroundings seemed to dream for them, all things smiled upon them.
zh: 周围的一切仿佛都在为他们制造梦境，所有的一切都好像在向他们微笑。

en: Then weighty matters recalled M. de Nueil to France.
zh: 一件关系重大的事情要求德纽埃尔先生必须回到法国。

en: His father and brother died, and he was obliged to leave Geneva.
zh: 他的父亲和哥哥去世了，他必须离开日内瓦。

en: The lovers bought the house; and if they could have had their way, they would have removed the hills piecemeal, drawn off the lake with a siphon, and taken everything away with them.
zh: 这对情侣已买下这栋房子；要是可能的话，他们真想将群山粉碎，用吸管吸干湖水，把这一切都统统带走。

en: Mme. de Beauseant followed M. de Nueil.
zh: 德鲍赛昂夫人跟随德纽埃尔先生一起回去了。

en: She realized her property, and bought a considerable estate near Manerville, adjoining Gaston’s lands, and here they lived together; Gaston very graciously giving up Manerville to his mother for the present in consideration of the bachelor freedom in which she left him.
zh: 她变卖了财产，在玛奈维尔附近购买了一大片地皮，和加斯东的土地毗邻，他们就在那里住下了；加斯东考虑只要母亲给他以自由之身，他便会欣然将玛奈维尔地产的使用权交给她。

en: Mme. de Beauseant’s estate was close to a little town in one of the most picturesque spots in the valley of the Auge.
zh: 德鲍赛昂夫人的房子就坐落在一座小城附近，位于奥日河谷最美丽的地段。

en: Here the lovers raised barriers between themselves and social intercourse, barriers which no creature could overleap, and here the happy days of Switzerland were lived over again.
zh: 两个情人在他们和社会交际之间设置了鸿沟，任何人都无法逾越的鸿沟，他们又恢复了往日在瑞士生活的幸福美好时光。

en: For nine whole years they knew happiness which it serves no purpose to describe; happiness which may be divined from the outcome of the story by those whose souls can comprehend poetry and prayer in their infinite manifestations.
zh: 九年来，他们过着毋庸细数的幸福生活；这样的生活务必会使那些能够理解各种各样形式的诗歌和祈祷的人，猜想到其中的幸福滋味。

en: All this time Mme. de Beauseant’s husband, the present Marquis (his father and elder brother having died), enjoyed the soundest health.
zh: 德鲍赛昂夫人的丈夫，现在的侯爵先生（他的父亲和哥哥已经去世），身体非常健康。

en: There is no better aid to life than a certain knowledge that our demise would confer a benefit on some fellow-creature.
zh: 要是能确实知道我们的死能够给别的什么人带来幸福的话，那么没有什么原因能够帮助我们更好地坚持活下去了。

en: M. de Beauseant was one of those ironical and wayward beings who, like holders of life-annuities, wake with an additional sense of relish every morning to a consciousness of good health.
zh: 德鲍赛昂先生性格执拗，刚愎自用，他和别的享受终身年金的人一样，认为只要每天早晨起床发觉自己精神饱满，便比别人都多一层不能享受的畅快感觉。

en: For the rest, he was a man of the world, somewhat methodical and ceremonious, and a calculator of consequences, who could make a declaration of love as quietly as a lackey announces that “Madame is served.”
zh: 至于其他，他是个饱经世故者，做事讲求方法和仪式，精于心计，他对女人倾诉爱情就像仆人平静地说“夫人，开饭了。”

en: This brief biographical notice of his lordship the Marquis de Beauseant is given to explain the reasons why it was impossible for the Marquise to marry M. de Nueil.
zh: 这一小段有关德鲍赛昂先生的传记，给大家以解释的目的是想说明侯爵夫人要嫁给德纽埃尔先生是不可能的。

en: So, after a nine years’ lease of happiness, the sweetest agreement to which a woman ever put her hand, M. de Nueil and Mme. de Beauseant were still in a position quite as natural and quite as false as at the beginning of their adventure.
zh: 九年的幸福租约，对一位女人来说是她所能签订的最甜美的约定，德纽埃尔先生和德鲍赛昂夫人依然处在一种自开头以来就既自然又虚假的局面里。

en: And yet they had reached a fatal crisis, which may be stated as clearly as any problem in mathematics.
zh: 这样的危机如此严重，也许只能用数学才能将它标注清楚。

en: Mme. la Comtesse de Nueil, Gaston’s mother, a strait-laced and virtuous person, who had made the late Baron happy in strictly legal fashion would never consent to meet Mme. de Beauseant.
zh: 德纽埃尔伯爵夫人是一位固守道德、品德端正的女人，她曾经完全遵循法律的要求给加斯东的父亲以幸福的生活，不过她从不愿意会见德鲍赛昂夫人。

en: Mme. de Beauseant quite understood that the worthy dowager must of necessity be her enemy, and that she would try to draw Gaston from his unhallowed and immoral way of life.
zh: 德鲍赛昂夫人非常明白这位可敬的贵妇必定是她的敌人，于是想尽办法将加斯东从这种不圣洁的、不道德的生活中挽救出来。

en: The Marquise de Beauseant would willingly have sold her property and gone back to Geneva, but she could not bring herself to do it; it would mean that she distrusted M. de Nueil.
zh: 德鲍赛昂侯爵夫人本想变卖田产回到日内瓦去，可是她不能这样做；这意味着她对德纽埃尔先生的不信任。

en: Moreover, he had taken a great fancy to this very Valleroy estate, where he was making plantations and improvements.
zh: 况且，他对瓦勒卢阿的土地十分的感兴趣，他在那里栽种植物，开垦土地。

en: She would not deprive him of a piece of pleasurable routine-work, such as women always wish for their husbands, and even for their lovers.
zh: 她不会剥夺他这种日常工作所带来的幸福，就像女人总是希望她们的丈夫，甚至她们的情人享有这种幸福一样。

en: A Mlle. de la Rodiere, twenty-two years of age, an heiress with a rent-roll of forty thousand livres, had come to live in the neighborhood.
zh: 一位芳龄22、名叫德拉·罗迪埃的小姐来到了这个地方，每年有四万里弗赫的年金入账。

en: Gaston always met her at Manerville whenever he was obliged to go thither.
zh: 加斯东每次去玛奈维尔去，总能碰到她。

en: These various personages being to each other as the terms of a proportion sum, the following letter will throw light on the appalling problem which Mme. de Beauseant had been trying for the past month to solve:—
zh: 这些形形色色的人物排列在那里，就像比例式的数字，鲍赛昂夫人一个月来一直在开动脑筋试图解决这个可怕的问题，下面这封信便可以作出解释：

en: “My beloved angel, it seems like nonsense, does it not, to write to you when there is nothing to keep us apart, when a caress so often takes the place of words, and words too are caresses?
zh: “我亲爱的天使，这样说简直是废话，没有什么能够使我们分离，我们的爱抚常常代替我们的语言，而此刻我给你写信难道不是太不合情理了吗？

en: Ah, well, no, love.
zh: 哦，好吧，不，亲爱的。

en: There are some things that a woman cannot say when she is face to face with the man she loves; at the bare thought of them her voice fails her, and the blood goes back to her heart; she has no strength, no intelligence left.
zh: 有些事情，一个女人当着她爱人的面是说不出口的；一想到这些事情，她就变得哑口无言，血液就会倒流回心脏；她没有了体力也没有了理智。

en: It hurts me to feel like this when you are near me, and it happens often.
zh: 当你在我身边时我感觉如此，而且时有发生，这令我痛苦难过。

en: I feel that my heart should be wholly sincere for you; that I should disguise no thought, however transient, in my heart; and I love the sweet carelessness, which suits me so well, too much to endure this embarrassment and constraint any longer.
zh: 我觉得我的心应该完全忠实于你；我不应对你掩饰任何想法，即便是在我心中转瞬即逝的思想；我喜爱这种美妙的无拘无束，这很适合我，我不愿意忍受困窘，变得不自由。

en: So I will tell you about my anguish—yes, it is anguish.
zh: 所以我告诉你我的痛苦——是的，痛苦。

en: Listen to me! do not begin with the little ‘Tut, tut, tut,’ that you use to silence me, an impertinence that I love, because anything from you pleases me.
zh: 听我说！不要用‘嘘，嘘，嘘，’这种无礼的语调来阻止我说下去，虽然我是爱听你这么说的，因为凡是你说的，无论什么我都喜欢。

en: Dear soul from heaven, wedded to mine, let me first tell you that you have effaced all memory of the pain that once was crushing the life out of me.
zh: 亲爱的我的天上佳人，让我先告诉你，过去的生活重压让我痛苦，是你将所有的这些痛苦记忆完全抹去了。

en: I did not know what love was before I knew you.
zh: 在我认识你之前，我并不知爱情究竟为何物。

en: Only the candor of your beautiful young life, only the purity of that great soul of yours, could satisfy the requirements of an exacting woman’s heart.
zh: 只有你青春靓丽的率真，由你伟大心灵的纯真，才能满足一位苛求少妇的心愿。

en: Dear love, how very often I have thrilled with joy to think that in these nine long, swift years, my jealousy has not been once awakened.
zh: 亲爱的，一想到九年来，这漫长而又短暂的九年里，我一次也未曾嫉妒过，我就高兴地发抖。

en: All the flowers of your soul have been mine, all your thoughts.
zh: 你把你所有的灵魂之花、所有的思想都给了我。

en: There has not been the faintest cloud in our heaven; we have not known what sacrifice is; we have always acted on the impulses of our hearts.
zh: 在我们的天空中不曾有丝毫阴云；我们从来不知道何为牺牲；我们总是按心灵的指示行事。

en: I have known happiness, infinite for a woman.
zh: 我也体验了对一个女人来说那最无边的幸福。

en: Will the tears that drench this sheet tell you all my gratitude?
zh: 我的泪水湿透了信纸，不知这是否能向你表达我的全部感激之情？

en: I could wish that I had knelt to write the words!—Well, out of this felicity has arisen torture more terrible than the pain of desertion.
zh: 我正想跪着写这封信！——这种幸福却令我感觉到比遗弃更可怕的痛苦。

en: Dear, there are very deep recesses in a woman’s heart; how deep in my own heart, I did not know myself until to-day, as I did not know the whole extent of love.
zh: 亲爱的，女人的心深不可测；直到今天我也不知道自己心的深度，就像我不知道爱的深度一样。

en: The greatest misery which could overwhelm us is a light burden compared with the mere thought of harm for him whom we love.
zh: 只要一想到我们所爱的人所遭受的不幸，我们所承受的最大不幸也就不知轻了多少倍。

en: And how if we cause the harm, is it not enough to make one die?...
zh: 要是这些伤害是我们造成的，那不是让我们痛不欲生了吗？

en: This is the thought that is weighing upon me.
zh: 这个想法一直压抑着我的思想。

en: But it brings in its train another thought that is heavier far, a thought that tarnishes the glory of love, and slays it, and turns it into a humiliation which sullies life as long as it lasts.
zh: 不过这个思想又带来了另一种更加沉重的思想，它会夺去爱情的光耀，扼杀爱情，将它变为耻辱，永远玷污人生。

en: You are thirty years old; I am forty.
zh: 你30岁了，而我40岁。

en: What dread this difference in age calls up in a woman who loves!
zh: 这样的念头难道不会使一位痴情女人千惶百恐吗！

en: It is possible that, first of all unconsciously, afterwards in earnest, you have felt the sacrifices that you have made by renouncing all in the world for me.
zh: 你为我做出了牺牲，抛弃了世间的一切，你起初可能会不自觉地，后来会认真地感觉到这些牺牲的。

en: Perhaps you have thought of your future from the social point of view, of the marriage which would, of course, increase your fortune, and give you avowed happiness and children who would inherit your wealth; perhaps you have thought of reappearing in the world, and filling your place there honorably.
zh: 也许你会考虑到你的社交前途、你将来可能的婚姻，当然是能够增加你财产的婚姻，允许你公开承认幸福和能够继承你财产的子女；也许你曾想过要再现于这个世界，从而体面地占据应有的位置。

en: And then, if so, you must have repressed those thoughts, and felt glad to sacrifice heiress and fortune and a fair future to me without my knowledge.
zh: 那么，你一定是压制住了这些思想，在我不知情的情况下，欣然牺牲了一个女继承人、一笔财产和一个美好的前途。

en: In your young man’s generosity, you must have resolved to be faithful to the vows which bind us each to each in the sight of God.
zh: 你拥有年轻人的慷慨，你决心信守誓言，尽管此誓言仅仅在上帝面前才具有约束力。

en: My past pain has risen up before your mind, and the misery from which you rescued me has been my protection.
zh: 过去的痛苦浮现在我的脑海中，你将我从不幸中挽救出的，而这份不幸却已然成了我的保护。

en: To owe your love to your pity!
zh: 你爱我完全是出于对我的怜悯！

en: The thought is even more painful to me than the fear of spoiling your life for you.
zh: 这个想法比害怕耽误了你一生的想法更让我疼痛难忍啊。

en: The man who can bring himself to stab his mistress is very charitable if he gives her her deathblow while she is happy and ignorant of evil, while illusions are in full blossom....
zh: 那些用匕首刺杀他们情妇的人是仁慈的，只要在他们给予致命一击时，情妇们是幸福的、无辜的，是充满幻想的……

en: Yes, death is preferable to the two thoughts which have secretly saddened the hours for several days.
zh: 是的，死亡比我这几天暗自悲痛地冒出的两个思想更为可取。

en: To-day, when you asked ‘What ails you?’ so tenderly, the sound of your voice made me shiver.
zh: 今天，当你问我‘你有什么心事吗？’你的声音如此温柔，让我不禁战栗。

en: I thought that, after your wont, you were reading my very soul, and I waited for your confidence to come, thinking that my presentiments had come true, and that I had guessed all that was going on in your mind.
zh: 我想，按照你的习惯，你定会看穿我的心思，我等待着你说出心里话，想象着我的预感马上变为现实，我以为我已经猜透了你心中的想法。

en: Then I began to think over certain little things that you always do for me, and I thought I could see in you the sort of affection by which a man betrays a consciousness that his loyalty is becoming a burden.
zh: 然后我开始想起某些你曾为我做过的点点滴滴，我认为我在你身上看到了一种爱，男人会因此感到忠诚正悄然变成一种负担。

en: And in that moment I paid very dear for my happiness.
zh: 那一刻，我觉得我为自己的幸福付出了太大的代价。

en: I felt that Nature always demands the price for the treasure called love.
zh: 我觉得大自然总是要为那份所谓爱的珍宝索要价钱。

en: Briefly, has not fate separated us?
zh: 一句话，命运不是已经将我们分离了吗？

en: Can you have said, ‘Sooner or later I must leave poor Claire; why not separate in time?’
zh: 你心里一定会想，‘我迟早会离开可怜的克莱尔；为什么不趁早离开呢？’

en: I read that thought in the depths of your eyes, and went away to cry by myself.
zh: 我从你的目光深处看到了这种思想，我离你而去，独自哭泣。

en: Hiding my tears from you!
zh: 不让你看到我流泪！

en: the first tears that I have shed for sorrow for these ten years; I am too proud to let you see them, but I did not reproach you in the least.
zh: 十年了，我第一次因为悲伤而哭泣；我太骄傲了不愿让你看到泪水，不过我可丝毫没有谴责你的意思。

en: “Yes, you are right.
zh: “是的，你说的有道理。

en: I ought not to be so selfish as to bind your long and brilliant career to my so-soon out-worn life....
zh: 我不该如此自私，将你那悠长而光辉的一生和我这即将衰逝生命缠在一起……

en: And yet—how if I have been mistaken?
zh: 可是——如果是我错了呢？

en: How if I have taken your love melancholy for a deliberation?
zh: 如果我把你忧郁的爱当成是一种从容的思考了呢？

en: Oh, my love, do not leave me in suspense; punish this jealous wife of yours, but give her back the sense of her love and yours; the whole woman lies in that—that consciousness sanctifies everything.
zh: 哦，我的爱，不要让我心神不宁啦；惩罚你这嫉妒的妻子吧，可是你必须让她意识到她的爱和你的爱；女人的一切都在于此——这种感情使一切变得神圣起来。

en: “Since your mother came, since you paid a visit to Mlle.
zh: “自从你母亲来后，自从你见到了德拉·罗迪埃小姐以后。

en: de Rodiere, I have been gnawed by doubts dishonoring to us both.
zh: 我就一直受到怀疑的折磨，这些怀疑让我丢尽了面子。

en: Make me suffer for this, but do not deceive me; I want to know everything that your mother said and that you think!
zh: 让我为此而受苦吧，不过，可不要欺骗我；我想知道你妈对你所说的一切以及你的想法。

en: If you have hesitated between some alternative and me, I give you back your liberty....
zh: 如果你在我和某些其他选择之间犹豫不决的话，我会给你自由……

en: I will not let you know what happens to me; I will not shed tears for you to see; only—I will not see you again....
zh: 我不会让你知道我的处境；我也不会让你看到我流泪；只不过——我不想再见到你了……

en: Ah! I cannot go on, my heart is breaking..................
zh: 啊！我写不下去了，我的心都碎了……

en: I have been sitting  benumbed and stupid for some moments.
zh: 我呆呆地僵坐在那里有一阵子。

en: Dear love, I do not find that any feeling of pride rises against you; you are so kind-hearted, so open; you would find it impossible to hurt me or to deceive me; and you will tell me the truth, however cruel it may be.
zh: 我的爱人，我找不到任何傲慢之心和你对抗；你是如此善良、坦诚；你是不可能伤害我或者欺骗我的；无论结果有多残酷，你都要告诉我事实的真相。

en: Do you wish me to encourage your confession?
zh: 你要我鼓励你说出实话吗？

en: Well, then, heart of mine, I shall find comfort in a woman’s thought.
zh: 那么，我的心肝，我会以妇人的思想来寻求慰藉。

en: Has not the youth of your being been mine, your sensitive, wholly gracious, beautiful, and delicate youth?
zh: 我不是曾经占有过你的青春吗？你那时机敏、优雅、漂亮而俊秀。

en: No woman shall find henceforth the Gaston whom I have known, nor the delicious happiness that he has given me....
zh: 没有哪个女人会再见到我所了解的加斯东，也不会有人能够享受得到他曾带给我的甜蜜幸福。

en: No; you will never love again as you have loved, as you love me now; no, I shall never have a rival, it is impossible.
zh: 不，你不会像曾经爱我那样，像现在爱我那样地去爱别人；不，我是绝不会有对手的，这是不可能的。

en: There will be no bitterness in my memories of our love, and I shall think of nothing else.
zh: 想到我们的爱，回忆中便不再有痛苦，我也不会再想什么其他的。

en: It is out of your power to enchant any woman henceforth by the childish provocations, the charming ways of a young heart, the soul’s winning charm, the body’s grace, the swift communion of rapture, the whole divine cortege of young love, in fine.
zh: 你再也不能用孩子般的撒娇，年轻心灵的迷人魅力，灵魂的内在风情，身体的优雅体态，以及对狂喜的迅速感悟，总之，一个年轻恋人所具备的一切可爱优点，去迷惑别的女人了。

en: “Oh, you are a man now, you will obey your destiny, weighing and considering all things.
zh: “哦，你已经是成人了，你会遵从命运的安排，权衡考虑一切事物。

en: You will have cares, and anxieties, and ambitions, and concerns that will rob her of the unchanging smile that made your lips fair for me.
zh: 你会担心、忧虑、野心勃勃、前思后想。这一切会夺去她不变的微笑，而对我而言，这微笑会使你的嘴唇更具美感。

en: The tones that were always so sweet for me will be troubled at times; and your eyes that lighted up with radiance from heaven at the sight of me, will often be lustreless for her.
zh: 对我而言，总是那么温柔的语调有时也会变得悲伤；你看到我时的眼睛总是闪烁着天籁之光，对着她可能会经常变得黯然失色。

en: And besides, as it is impossible to love you as I love you, you will never care for that woman as you have cared for me.
zh: 还有，那个女人永远不可能像我那样地爱你，你也从来不会像喜欢我一样地去喜欢那个女人。

en: She will never keep a constant watch over herself as I have done; she will never study your happiness at every moment with an intuition which has never failed me.
zh: 她不会像我一样总是留心自己的装扮；她也绝不会思考你的幸福，而在这方面我的直觉是绝不会辜负你的。

en: Ah, yes, the man, the heart and soul, which I shall have known will exist no longer.
zh: 哦，是的，那个人，他的心灵和灵魂，那个我所熟悉的人，已经不复存在了。

en: I shall bury him deep in my memory, that I may have the joy of him still; I shall live happy in that fair past life of ours, a life hidden from all but our inmost selves.
zh: 我将把这一切都埋在记忆的深处，不过我依然会体验到他的快乐；我将幸福地生活在过去的美好时光里，这些日子隐藏在我们的内心深处，没有人知晓。

en: “Dear treasure of mine, if all the while no least thought of liberty has risen in your mind, if my love is no burden on you, if my fears are chimerical, if I am still your Eve—the one woman in the world for you—come to me as soon as you have read this letter, come quickly!
zh: “我亲爱的宝贝，也许你从来没有想过要享受自由，也许爱情对你并非负担，如果我的恐惧只是空想，如果我依然是你的夏娃——对你而言这个世界唯一的女人——那你读完这封信后来到我身边吧，快快来吧！

en: Ah, in one moment I will love you more than I have ever loved you, I think, in these nine years.
zh: 啊，这一刻，我想，在这九年里，我比任何时候都更爱你。

en: After enduring the needless torture of these doubts of which I am accusing myself, every added day of love, yes, every single day, will be a whole lifetime of bliss.
zh: 我责难自己提出过种种怀疑，忍受了由此产生的无谓痛苦之后，我们的爱情每过一天，是的，只要一天，就等同于幸福的一辈子。

en: So speak, and speak openly; do not deceive me, it would be a crime.
zh: 因此说吧，坦率地说吧；不要骗我，那将是一桩罪。

en: Tell me, do you wish for your liberty?
zh: 告诉我，你希望我给你自由吗？

en: Have you thought of all that a man’s life means?
zh: 你想过真正男人生活的意义吗？

en: Is there any regret in your mind?
zh: 你后悔过吗？

en: That I should cause you a regret!
zh: 要是我让你后悔过！

en: I should die of it.
zh: 我宁愿去死！

en: I have said it: I love you enough to set your happiness above mine, your life before my own.
zh: 我曾经说过：我深爱着你，我把你的幸福置于我的幸福之上，把你的生命看得比我的生命更重要。

en: Leave on one side, if you can, the wealth of memories of our nine years’ happiness, that they may not influence your decision, but speak!
zh: 如果能的话，把我们九年的幸福时光暂搁一旁，不要让它影响了你的决定，尽管说吧！

en: I submit myself to you as to God, the one Consoler who remains if you forsake me.”
zh: 我会像顺从上帝般地顺从你，如果你抛弃了我，那么就只剩下上帝是我唯一的安慰者了。”

en: When Mme. de Beauseant knew that her letter was in M. de Nueil’s hands, she sank in such utter prostration, the over-pressure of many thoughts so numbed her faculties, that she seemed almost drowsy.
zh: 德鲍赛昂夫人得知这封信已到达德纽埃尔先生的手中之后，便全身瘫软，精疲力竭，思绪纷乱，如千斤重压使自己失去知觉，看上去昏昏欲睡。

en: At any rate, she was suffering from a pain not always proportioned in its intensity to a woman’s strength; pain which women alone know.
zh: 毕竟，她所承受的痛苦，其强烈程度超过了一般妇女所能忍受的限度；此种痛苦只有女人才能感受得到。

en: And while the unhappy Marquise awaited her doom, M. de Nueil, reading her letter, felt that he was “in a very difficult position,” to use the expression that young men apply to a crisis of this kind.
zh: 当可怜的侯爵夫人等待着自己的宿命决定时，德纽埃尔先生此刻正读着她的信，用年轻人碰到此类变故时常使用的字眼来说，他的“处境相当尴尬”。

en: By this time he had all but yielded to his mother’s importunities and to the attractions of Mlle. de la Rodiere, a somewhat insignificant, pink-and-white young person, as straight as a poplar.
zh: 此刻她已经完全屈服于妈妈的强压和德拉·罗迪埃小姐的吸引力了，这位年轻的小姐平平庸庸，皮肤白里透红，身体如白杨树般僵直。

en: It is true that, in accordance with the rules laid down for marriageable young ladies, she scarcely opened her mouth, but her rent-roll of forty thousand livres spoke quite sufficiently for her.
zh: 确实，按照待嫁妇女需遵循的标准而言，她几乎相当于是半个哑巴，不过她每年四万里弗赫的地租已经足以为她说话了。

en: Mme. de Nueil, with a mother’s sincere affection, tried to entangle her son in virtuous courses.
zh: 德纽埃尔夫人用妈妈的真挚情感，试图将她的儿子拉回到道德的正路上来。

en: She called his attention to the fact that it was a flattering distinction to be preferred by Mlle. de la Rodiere, who had refused so many great matches; it was quite time, she urged, that he should think of his future, such a good opportunity might not repeat itself, some day he would have eighty thousand livres of income from land; money made everything bearable; if Mme. de Beauseant loved him for his own sake, she ought to be the first to urge him to marry.
zh: 她向他指出，能被德拉·罗迪埃小姐选中实在是令人高兴，她可是曾经拒绝过很多的求婚者啊；这正是他要考虑自己前途的时机，她也强烈催促此事，这种时机不可多得，将来总有一天他会拥有八万里弗赫的年息；钱可以安慰一切；如果德·鲍赛昂夫人真心爱他的话，应该第一个敦促他结婚的。

en: In short, the well-intentioned mother forgot no arguments which the feminine intellect can bring to bear upon the masculine mind, and by these means she had brought her son into a wavering condition.
zh: 总之，这位善良的母亲没有忘记运用女人能够影响男人理智的所有手段，通过这些方法，她将儿子带入了左右摇摆的境地之中。

en: Mme. de Beauseant’s letter arrived just as Gaston’s love of her was holding out against the temptations of a settled life conformable to received ideas.
zh: 德鲍赛昂夫人的信到达的时候，加斯东的爱情正按照世俗的观念与种种诱惑进行着激烈的斗争。

en: That letter decided the day.
zh: 这封信决定了斗争的胜负。

en: He made up his mind to break off with the Marquise and to marry.
zh: 他决心离开侯爵夫人，跟别人结婚。

en: “One must live a man’s life,” said he to himself.
zh: “人要活得堂堂正正。”他对自己说道。

en: Then followed some inkling of the pain that this decision would give to Mme. de Beauseant.
zh: 然后他思忖着他的决定可能会给德鲍赛昂夫人带来什么样的痛苦。

en: The man’s vanity and the lover’s conscience further exaggerated this pain, and a sincere pity for her seized upon him.
zh: 男人的虚荣心以及情人的良心将这种痛苦进一步加重，对她的恻隐之心阵阵涌上心头。

en: All at once the immensity of the misery became apparent to him, and he thought it necessary and charitable to deaden the deadly blow.
zh: 突然间他感到一种巨大的不幸，他觉得减轻这致命的一击是有必要而且仁慈的举动。

en: He hoped to bring Mme. de Beauseant to a calm frame of mind by gradually reconciling her to the idea of separation; while Mlle. de la Rodiere, always like a shadowy third between them, should be sacrificed to her at first, only to be imposed upon her later.
zh: 他想通过使她逐渐习惯分手的念头的方法，希望能够引导德鲍赛昂夫人保持冷静；而且德拉·罗迪埃小姐总是如影子一般地出现在他们中间，开始先牺牲这位小姐，然后再设法让人逼他娶她。

en: His marriage should take place later, in obedience to Mme. de Beauseant’s expressed wish.
zh: 他应该随后结婚，这也是顺从了德鲍赛昂夫人的心愿。

en: He went so far as to enlist the Marquise’s nobleness and pride and all the great qualities of her nature to help him to succeed in this compassionate design.
zh: 他尽数侯爵夫人的高贵、自尊以及她性格中所有重要的品质，以保证这桩极富同情心的计划得以成功。

en: He would write a letter at once to allay her suspicions.
zh: 他便立刻写了一封信来消除她的怀疑。

en: @A letter!@
zh: 一封信！

en: For a woman with the most exquisite feminine perception, as well as the intuition of passionate love, a letter in itself was a sentence of death.
zh: 对于一个具有最细腻感觉和拥有最热烈爱情直觉的女人而言，信本身就是死亡的判决书。

en: So when Jacques came and brought Mme. de Beauseant a sheet of paper folded in a triangle, she trembled, poor woman, like a snared swallow.
zh: 因此当雅克走进来，递给德鲍赛昂夫人一封折成三角的信纸时，她浑身颤抖，像一只被捕的燕子，可怜的女人。

en: A mysterious sensation of physical cold spread from head to foot, wrapping her about in an icy winding sheet.
zh: 一股莫名的寒气从头落到脚，如同将她包裹在冰凉的裹尸布里。

en: If he did not rush to her feet, if he did not come to her in tears, and pale, and like a lover, she knew that all was lost.
zh: 如果他没有跑过来时跪倒在她的膝下，没有跑过来时像情人一样泪流满面、脸色苍白的话，她就知道大势已去了。

en: And yet, so many hopes are there in the heart of a woman who loves, that she is only slain by stab after stab, and loves on till the last drop of life-blood drains away.
zh: 然而，痴情的女人心中总是充满着无数的希望，要拿匕首刺无数次才能将它杀死，不到为爱流尽最后一滴血决不会罢休。

en: “Does madame need anything?” Jacques asked gently, as he went away.
zh: “夫人还需要些什么吗？”雅克离开时轻声地问道。

en: “No,” she said.
zh: “不用了。”她回答。

en: “Poor fellow!” she thought, brushing a tear from her eyes, “he guesses my feelings, servant though he is!”
zh: “可怜的人啊！”她拭去眼角的泪滴想着，“虽是仆人，却也已猜透了我的心思！”

en: She read: “My beloved, you are inventing idle terrors for yourself...”
zh: 她读到：“亲爱的，你真是在自己吓唬自己啊……”

en: The Marquise gazed at the words, and a thick mist spread before her eyes.
zh: 子爵夫人盯着这几个字，一层浓雾遮盖住她的双眼。

en: A voice in her heart cried, “He lies!”
zh: 在她的心中有一种声音在哭喊：“他撒谎！”

en: —Then she glanced down the page with the clairvoyant eagerness of passion, and read these words at the foot, “Nothing has been decided as yet...”
zh: ——然后她怀着明察秋毫、心急火燎的心情迅速地浏览完信，在这页的下边写着这样一些话，“一切都还没有确定……”

en: Turning to the other side with convulsive quickness, she saw the mind of the writer distinctly through the intricacies of the wording; this was no spontaneous outburst of love.
zh: 她抽搐似的迅速翻过一页，从这些错综复杂的措词当中清楚地看出了作者的思想，这再也没有自然迸发的爱情可言了。

en: She crushed it in her fingers, twisted it, tore it with her teeth, flung it in the fire, and cried aloud, “Ah! base that he is!
zh: 她用手将信压皱，把它揉成一团，再用牙将其撕碎，投入火中，便号啕大哭起来：“啊！他好卑鄙！

en: I was his, and he had ceased to love me!”
zh: 他已不再爱我了，却还想占有我！”

en: She sank half dead upon the couch.
zh: 她半死不活地倾倒在长榻上。

en: M. de Nueil went out as soon as he had written his letter.
zh: 德纽埃尔先生一写完信后便外出了。

en: When he came back, Jacques met him on the threshold with a note.
zh: 当他回来时，雅克手拿一封信站在门口。

en: “Madame la Marquise has left the chateau,” said the man.
zh: “侯爵夫人已经离开了城堡。”他说。

en: M. de Nueil, in amazement, broke the seal and read:—
zh: 德纽埃尔先生，很是惊讶，他打开信封读道：

en: “MADAME,—If I could cease to love you, to take the chances of becoming an ordinary man which you hold out to me, you must admit that I should thoroughly deserve my fate.
zh: “夫人，——如果我能够停止爱你，像你说得成为一个普通人的话，那么你一定会承认，我就活该倒霉了。

en: No, I shall not do as you bid me; the oath of fidelity which I swear to you shall only be absolved by death.
zh: 不，我不会听从你的命令，我会坚持我的忠诚誓言直到死亡。

en: Ah! take my life, unless indeed you do not fear to carry a remorse all through your own...”
zh: 啊，把我的命带走吧，除非你不怕在你的生命中徒增责备……”

en: It was his own letter, written to the Marquise as she set out for Geneva nine years before.
zh: 这是九年前伯爵夫人动身去日内瓦时他写给她的信。

en: At the foot of it Claire de Bourgogne had written, “Monsieur, you are free.”
zh: 在信的下面，克莱尔·德勃艮第写着：“先生，你自由了。”

en: M. de Nueil went to his mother at Manerville.
zh: 德纽埃尔先生回到在玛奈维尔的母亲那里。

en: In less than three weeks he married Mlle. Stephanie de la Rodiere.
zh: 三个星期不到，他就娶了斯泰法妮德·拉·罗迪埃小姐。

en: If this commonplace story of real life ended here, it would be to some extent a sort of mystification.
zh: 如果这真实而又平凡的故事就此结束的话，那么这在一定程度上会给人一种让摸不着头脑的感觉。

en: The first man you meet can tell you a better.
zh: 谁也没有比这更有意思的故事可讲了。

en: But the widespread fame of the catastrophe (for, unhappily, this is a true tale), and all the memories which it may arouse in those who have known the divine delights of infinite passion, and lost them by their own deed, or through the cruelty of fate,—these things may perhaps shelter the story from criticism.
zh: 不过这个不幸的故事却广为人知（因为，不幸的是，这是个真实的故事），还有，有些人体验过无上爱情非凡快乐的滋味，却又亲手毁灭了这幸福，或者这幸福被残酷的命运破坏了，头脑中产生出无数的回忆，——这些也许都可以使这片故事免受批评。

en: Mme. la Marquise de Beauseant never left Valleroy after her parting from M. de Nueil.
zh: 德鲍·赛昂侯爵夫人和德纽埃尔先生分离之后，她根本就没有离开过瓦勒卢阿古堡。

en: After his marriage she still continued to live there, for some inscrutable woman’s reason; any woman is at liberty to assign the one which most appeals to her.
zh: 由于种种只能埋藏在女人心中的难以预测的原因，任何一个女人都能想出专属于她们自己的理由，在他结婚之后，伯爵夫人依然继续住在那里。

en: Claire de Bourgogne lived in such complete retirement that none of the servants, save Jacques and her own woman, ever saw their mistress.
zh: 克莱尔·德勃艮第过着完全秘密的隐居生活，除了雅克之外，其他任何仆人和贴身女仆都不曾见过她。

en: She required absolute silence all about her, and only left her room to go to the chapel on the Valleroy estate, whither a neighboring priest came to say mass every morning.
zh: 她自己需要绝对的安静，除了到瓦勒卢阿的小教堂里去，她闭门不出，只有附近的一位牧师每天清晨来这里为她做弥撒。

en: The Comte de Nueil sank a few days after his marriage into something like conjugal apathy, which might be interpreted to mean happiness or unhappiness equally easily.
zh: 结婚之后没几天，德纽埃尔伯爵便陷入了夫妻关系平和的状态之中，这可以解释为幸福，也可以解释为不幸福。

en: “My son is perfectly happy,” his mother said everywhere.
zh: 她妈妈无论到哪里都会说：“我儿子相当幸福。”

en: Mme. Gaston de Nueil, like a great many young women, was a rather colorless character, sweet and passive.
zh: 加斯东·德纽埃尔夫人，跟许多别的少妇一样，性格有些无趣，温柔和顺从。

en: A month after her marriage she had expectations of becoming a mother.
zh: 婚后一个月，她就当妈妈了。

en: All this was quite in accordance with ordinary views.
zh: 这一切非常地切合固有的观念。

en: M. de Nueil was very nice to her; but two months after his separation from the Marquise, he grew notably thoughtful and abstracted.
zh: 德纽埃尔先生对她非常好；不过和伯爵夫人分手后两个月的时间里，他变得忧心忡忡，心不在焉。

en: But then he always had been serious, his mother said.
zh: 可是，他妈妈说，他儿子向来都是不苟言笑的。

en: After seven months of this tepid happiness, a little thing occurred, one of those seemingly small matters which imply such great development of thought and such widespread trouble of the soul, that only the bare fact can be recorded; the interpretation of it must be left to the fancy of each individual mind.
zh: 经历了七个月不温不火的幸福生活之后，发生了一件看似无足轻重的小事，然而这种小事却暗示着思想的大发展以及心灵的大烦恼，不能简单地加以叙述；要想解释得清楚就只好任凭人们去随意猜测了。

en: One day, when M. de Nueil had been shooting over the lands of Manerville and Valleroy, he crossed Mme. de Beauseant’s park on his way home, summoned Jacques, and when the man came, asked him, “Whether the Marquise was as fond of game as ever?”
zh: 一天，德纽埃尔先生在玛奈维尔和瓦勒卢阿的田野中打猎，回家时穿过德鲍赛昂夫人的花园，他招来雅克，雅克走了过来，便问他，“是不是伯爵夫人还一直喜欢吃野味呢？”

en: Jacques answering in the affirmative, Gaston offered him a good round sum (accompanied by plenty of specious reasoning) for a very little service.
zh: 雅克做出肯定的回答，加斯东给了他一大笔钱（外加一大堆似是而非的理由）作为小费，让他帮个小忙。

en: Would he set aside for the Marquise the game that the Count would bring?
zh: 他可否把伯爵带来的野味留给侯爵夫人？

en: It seemed to Jacques to be a matter of no great importance whether the partridge on which his mistress dined had been shot by her keeper or by M. de Nueil, especially since the latter particularly wished that the Marquise should know nothing about it.
zh: 雅克觉得这女主人吃的山鹑是由她的猎人打的还是由德纽埃尔先生打的并没有多大关系，因为后者特别不希望伯爵夫人知道这些野味的来历。

en: “It was killed on her land,” said the Count, and for some days Jacques lent himself to the harmless deceit.
zh: “这是在她的田里打的。”伯爵说道，而且一连好几天，雅克都参与了这个并无恶意的骗局当中。

en: Day after day M. de Nueil went shooting, and came back at dinner-time with an empty bag.
zh: 德纽埃尔先生日复一日地出门打猎，晚饭归来时从来都是两手空空。

en: A whole week went by in this way.
zh: 整个星期都是这样度过的。

en: Gaston grew bold enough to write a long letter to the Marquise, and had it conveyed to her.
zh: 加斯东胆子大了起来，给侯爵夫人写了一封长信，并设法将信送到她手中。

en: It was returned to him unopened.
zh: 信没有打开就退了回来。

en: The Marquise’s servant brought it back about nightfall.
zh: 侯爵夫人的仆人给他送回信的时候夜幕已经降临。

en: The Count, sitting in the drawing-room listening, while his wife at the piano mangled a Caprice of Herold’s, suddenly sprang up and rushed out to the Marquise, as if he were flying to an assignation.
zh: 伯爵坐在客厅里，听着妻子在钢琴旁刺耳地弹奏着埃拉尔德的随想曲，突然他站起身，向侯爵夫人家急奔过去，就像飞着去赴约一样。

en: He dashed through a well-known gap into the park, and went slowly along the avenues, stopping now and again for a little to still the loud beating of his heart.
zh: 他从一处熟悉的缺口跳进花园里，然后沿着径道慢慢地前行，时不时地停下来一小会儿，似乎要压抑一下怦怦的心跳声。

en: Smothered sounds as he came nearer the chateau told him that the servants must be at supper, and he went straight to Mme. de Beauseant’s room.
zh: 当他走进古堡时，听了一下周围的声响，断定仆人们在准备晚餐，于是便径直朝德鲍赛昂夫人的房间走了过去。

en: Mme. de Beauseant never left her bedroom.
zh: 德鲍赛昂夫人从不离开她的卧室。

en: M. de Nueil could gain the doorway without making the slightest sound.
zh: 德纽埃尔先生悄无声息地挨到卧室门口。

en: There, by the light of two wax candles, he saw the thin, white Marquise in a great armchair; her head was bowed, her hands hung listlessly, her eyes gazing fixedly at some object which she did not seem to see.
zh: 在那里，透过两只蜡烛的微光，他看到瘦弱苍白的侯爵夫人坐在一张大扶手椅上；她低着头，无精打采地垂下双手，眼睛直勾勾地盯着一件她似乎并看不到的物体。

en: Her whole attitude spoke of hopeless pain.
zh: 她的整个姿态表明了她绝望般的痛苦。

en: There was a vague something like hope in her bearing, but it was impossible to say whither Claire de Bourgogne was looking—forwards to the tomb or backwards into the past.
zh: 在这样的姿态里，好似有一种如希望般渺茫的事物，谁都不知道克莱尔·德勃艮第是在向着坟墓凝视呢，还是在向过去凝视。

en: Perhaps M. de Nueil’s tears glittered in the deep shadows; perhaps his breathing sounded faintly; perhaps unconsciously he trembled, or again it may have been impossible that he should stand there, his presence unfelt by that quick sense which grows to be an instinct, the glory, the delight, the proof of perfect love.
zh: 也许是因为德纽埃尔先生的眼泪在黑暗中闪烁；也许是因为他呼吸出微弱的声响；也许是因为他不自觉地颤抖，或者他站在那里是不可能感觉不到的现象，这种现象已成长为一种本能，光荣，喜悦和真爱的证明。

en: However it was, Mme. de Beauseant slowly turned her face towards the doorway, and beheld her lover of bygone days.
zh: 不管怎样，德鲍赛昂夫人慢慢地朝门口转过头来，看到了她往日的情人。

en: Then Gaston de Nueil came forward a few paces.
zh: 然后加斯东·德纽埃尔先前走了几步。

en: “If you come any further, sir,” exclaimed the Marquise, growing paler, “I shall fling myself out of the window!”
zh: “先生，如果你再靠近一步”伯爵夫人面色惨白地大声叫道，“我就从窗户跳下去！”

en: She sprang to the window, flung it open, and stood with one foot on the ledge, her hand upon the iron balustrade, her face turned towards Gaston.
zh: 她跳到窗前，猛地推开窗户，一只脚踏在窗台上，手扶住铁栏杆，头转过来朝向加斯东。

en: “Go out! go out!” she cried, “or I will throw myself over.”
zh: “出去！出去！”她喊道，“不然我就跳下去。”

en: At that dreadful cry the servants began to stir, and M. de Nueil fled like a criminal.
zh: 听到这可怕的哭喊声，仆人们开始骚动起来，德纽埃尔先生像罪犯一样逃跑了。

en: When he reached his home again he wrote a few lines and gave them to his own man, telling him to give the letter himself into Mme. de Beauseant’s hands, and to say that it was a matter of life and death for his master.
zh: 他再次回到家里时，他写了几句话，把它交给随身侍仆，告诉他要亲手交到德鲍赛昂夫人手上，并且告诉她这是关于他生死存亡的大事。

en: The messenger went.
zh: 信使出去了。

en: M. de Nueil went back to the drawing-room where his wife was still murdering the Caprice, and sat down to wait till the answer came.
zh: 德纽埃尔先生回到客厅，妻子依然在糟糕地弹奏那首随想曲，于是坐下来等待回音。

en: An hour later, when the Caprice had come to an end, and the husband and wife sat in silence on opposite sides of the hearth, the man came back from Valleroy and gave his master his own letter, unopened.
zh: 一个小时过后，随想曲弹完了，丈夫和妻子各自默默地在壁炉的两端，仆人从瓦勒卢阿回来了，把信原封不动地退回了给主人。

en: M. de Nueil went into a small room beyond the drawing-room, where he had left his rifle, and shot himself.
zh: 德纽埃尔先生穿过客厅走进一间放有猎枪的小屋，自杀身亡了。

en: The swift and fatal ending of the drama, contrary as it is to all the habits of young France, is only what might have been expected.
zh: 这个突然而致命的结局，跟年轻的法兰西人所习惯的完全相反，不过却是可以预料的。

en: Those who have closely observed, or known for themselves by delicious experience, all that is meant by the perfect union of two beings, will understand Gaston de Nueil’s suicide perfectly well.
zh: 那些曾仔细观察过，或者美好地体验过一对男女美满结合的人，会完全理解加斯东·德纽埃尔的自杀行为。

en: A woman does not bend and form herself in a day to the caprices of passion.
zh: 一个女人不会在一天之内就按照爱情的无常变化屈服或塑造自己。

en: The pleasure of loving, like some rare flower, needs the most careful ingenuity of culture.
zh: 爱的快乐，如一朵奇葩，需要最精心的呵护培养。

en: Time alone, and two souls attuned each to each, can discover all its resources, and call into being all the tender and delicate delights for which we are steeped in a thousand superstitions, imagining them to be inherent in the heart that lavishes them upon us.
zh: 只有经历时间，两个彼此结合的灵魂，才能发现快乐的源泉，产生温柔美妙的快乐，我们对它们充满了迷信，认为赐给我们快乐的心灵是与生俱来的。

en: It is this wonderful response of one nature to another, this religious belief, this certainty of finding peculiar or excessive happiness in the presence of one we love, that accounts in part for perdurable attachments and long-lived passion.
zh: 这是一种令人赞叹的融合，这种宗教信仰，这种在所爱的人身边所能感受到的奇特或者过分的幸福的确切观念，便是能够长久依恋和永远相爱的部分秘密。

en: If a woman possesses the genius of her sex, love never comes to be a matter of use and wont.
zh: 一个女人若拥有女性的天赋，那么爱情对她而言绝不会成为一种生活的习惯。

en: She brings all her heart and brain to love, clothes her tenderness in forms so varied, there is such art in her most natural moments, or so much nature in her art, that in absence her memory is almost as potent as her presence.
zh: 她会全心全意地去爱，采取各种不同的温情方式，在她的自然之中融入众多人为的技巧，或者在人为的技巧中增添许多天然的成分，使得她无论在记忆中还是在现实里都那么有影响力。

en: All other women are as shadows compared with her.
zh: 别的女人和她相比都会逊色很多。

en: Not until we have lost or known the dread of losing a love so vast and glorious, do we prize it at its just worth.
zh: 只有当我们已经失去或者已经知道了失去这么伟大而光荣的爱情的恐惧时，我们才能珍视爱情的应有价值。

en: And if a man who has once possessed this love shuts himself out from it by his own act and deed, and sinks to some loveless marriage; if by some incident, hidden in the obscurity of married life, the woman with whom he hoped to know the same felicity makes it clear that it will never be revived for him; if, with the sweetness of divine love still on his lips, he has dealt a deadly wound to her, his wife in truth, whom he forsook for a social chimera,—then he must either die or take refuge in a materialistic, selfish, and heartless philosophy, from which impassioned souls shrink in horror.
zh: 可是如果一个男人曾经拥有过这样的爱情，却又把它抛弃，去选择了一个无爱的婚姻；如果他希望能够在另一个女人身上获得同样的幸福，而这个女人却用隐匿在婚姻生活暗处的某些事件证明，他是不可能得到这幸福的；如果圣洁甜美的爱情还依然沾在他的唇边，而他又为着一个社会的假象深深地伤害了她，他真正的妻子，——那么他就必须要选择死亡或者在那令多情人所憎恶的自私、冷酷的唯利主义哲学中去寻求慰藉。

en: As for Mme. de Beauseant, she doubtless did not imagine that her friend’s despair could drive him to suicide, when he had drunk deep of love for nine years.
zh: 至于德鲍赛昂夫人，她绝对不会想到他的朋友会绝望到选择自杀，当年他可是深爱了九年之久啊。

en: Possibly she may have thought that she alone was to suffer.
zh: 也许她认为只有她一个人在忍受痛苦。

en: At any rate, she did quite rightly to refuse the most humiliating of all positions; a wife may stoop for weighty social reasons to a kind of compromise which a mistress is bound to hold in abhorrence, for in the purity of her passion lies all its justification.
zh: 况且，她完全有权利拒绝所有最为可耻的爱情；一位妻子可以为着重要的社会原因来容忍这种爱情，而一个情妇却痛恨这种勾当，因为对她而言，爱情存在的全部理由在于她爱情的纯洁。

en: ANGOULEME, September 1832.
zh: 1832年9月于昂古莱姆
